qas.question: What measurable value obeys a similar rule of angular momentum?
What forces measurement attempts to choose between trade-offs, in quanta?
What form do measurement attempt trade-offs for quanta take the form of?
How is uncertainly measured in this experience?

answers.text: the standard deviation of the measured value from its expected value

qas.question: What type of analysis fits the either-or nature of the uncertainty?
What example is given as another paired relationship of uncertainly related to standard deviation?
What measurable value avoids a similar rule of angular momentum?
What forces measurement never chooses between trade-offs, in quanta?
What form do measurement attempt trade-offs for quanta avoid?
What type of analysis fits the either-and nature of certainty?
What example is given as another paired relationship of certainty related to deviation?

context: where the uncertainty is given as <a3_0>the standard deviation of the measured value from its expected value<a3_0/>. There are a number of other such pairs of physically measurable values which obey a similar rule. One example is <a0_0><a5_0><b6_0><b10_0>time vs. energy<b10_0/><b6_0/><a5_0/><a0_0/>. The <a1_0><b7_0>either-or nature of uncertainty<b7_0/><a1_0/> forces measurement attempts to choose between trade offs, and given that they are quanta, the trade offs often take the form of <a2_0><b8_0>either-or (as in <a4_0><b9_0>Fourier analysis<b9_0/><a4_0/>)<b8_0/><a2_0/>, rather than the compromises and gray areas of time series analysis.
